title.narrative: Mechanism 18615 - Improving Comprehensive AIDS Response Enhanced for Sustainability (iCARES)_2098

description.narrative:
Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
Nigeria continues to be the largest annual contributor of new infant HIV infections with an estimated 41,000 new infections in 2015 accounting for 25% of the global total (UNAIDS). A total of 380,000 children were living with HIV in 2015 and only 17% of children living with HIV accessed antiretroviral therapy. With challenges in pediatric HIV diagnosis only 9% of HEI received EID in 2015. Estimate Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.8: Orphans and Vulnerable Children. Activities are aimed at improving the lives of orphans and other vulnerable children (OVC) affected by HIV/AIDS, and doing so in a measurable way. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.12: Laboratory Infrastructure. Development and strengthening of laboratory systems and facilities to support HIV/AIDSrelated activities including purchase of equipment and commodities and provision of quality assurance, staff training and other technical assistance. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

Nigeria continues to be the largest annual contributor of new infant HIV infections with an estimated 41,000 new infections in 2015 accounting for 25% of the global total (UNAIDS). A total of 380,000 children were living with HIV in 2015 and only 17% of children living with HIV accessed antiretroviral therapy. With challenges in pediatric HIV diagnosis only 9% of HEI received EID in 2015. Estimated orphans due to AIDS aged 0 to 17 was 1,800,000 in 2015.This TBD mechanism seeks to sustain the delivery of comprehensive HIV/AIDS prevention, care and treatment services that will result in increased access to treatment and reduced new infections in Nigeria. Activities to be implemented by this mechanism among others are HIV Prevention Services including HTS, combination prevention packages, prevention for key and priority populations; Care and Support services for PLHIV including prevention of opportunistic infections through CPT and IPT, diagnosis and management of OIs e.g. Cryptocococcal meningistis, TB etc; provision of life saving ART services for HIV infected adults, adolescents and children to reduce morbidity and mortality in this group. Also the mechanism will implement services targeted at prevention of mother to child transmission of HIV, care of HIV exposed infants and early infant diagnosis services. Also the mechanism will seek to provide comprehensive services for orphan and vulnerable children; support laboratory services for diagnosis and management of clients living with HIV. Other prevention services aimed at mitigating HIV infection and transmission including PrEP, Post-exposure prophylaxis, HIV medical transmission prevention services etc.

organisation.narrative: Office of the Global AIDS Coordinator

mailing-address.narrative: 2100 Pennsylvania Avenue, Suite 200, Washington, DC 20522, USA

policy-marker.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. government's response to the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and represents the largest commitment by any nation to address a single disease in history.
